Bob Armbruster: Suburbia At Its Best
By MICHAEL HILL
The putter deftly swings and the
ball rolls true down the hallway
carpet, breaking slightly right to
left as it crosses the office threshold,
finally rattling into the cup placed
next to the desk.
Robert Armbruster looks up, his
characteristically impish grin
broken only by the ever- present
tiparillo. Armbruster is editor of the
Johns Hopkins Magazine, one of the
best alumni publications in the
nation.
"I get impatient at times with the
academic types, their arrogance,
their 'we-know-it-and- they-don't'
attitude. But working in a University
around these people and their ideas,
helps to slow the inevitable process
of stagnation.
Placed in the precarious position
between the Univel Ly and its
alumni, the 36 year-old Armbruster
knows a great deal about communications gaps. "I don't understand the students quite often on
a lot of counts, but it doesn't worry •
me. Sure there's a generation gap,
but so what?"
The gap that worries Armbruster
Is between the alumni and their
alrna-mater. "All we can do is give

them a tiny example of what
Hopkins is; to try and make it seem
human." The Magazine tries to
make real •to a far-removed and
incredibly diverse readership the
problems not only of students but
also of faculty and administrators.
"We want them to form their own
opinions about the nature of the
place."
From his office on Charles Street,
Armbruster has probably dusted out
as many corners of the University
as anyone. "I'm optimistic. about
Hopkins and about the country.
Though I have mixed feelings about
them, the students at Hopkins are
interested in the right things,
needles in the right
sticking
places."
Armbruster describes himself as a
liberal Democratic. "I have faith in
the system, otherwise I wouldn't be
an editor." And indeed Armbruster
does have most of the trappings of
middle America. But his easy going
informality belies the fact that he
fits few of the stereotypes of the
straight world.
After graduating from Beloit
College, in 1956, Armbruster spent 9
months working for Bell Telephone.
"I hated it. They spent 2 weeks

Bob Irmbruster
teaching ne how to answer the phone
like an executive."
He found the army as dehumanizing until he lied his way
onto the post newspaper. "This was
my first taste of journalism and of
official conservatism." More of both
was to come as Armbruster worked

in various publicOlons positions in a
potpourri colleges and universities
before coming to Hopkins in 1968.
"The Hopkins Magazine is 1 of the
jobs everybody in the business
would like to have. I was lucky to
get it." The Magazine along with
similar publications from Simons
College and Washington University
was recently cited by the American
Alumni Council for continued excellence during the past decade.
Before coming here, Armbruster
spent 4 years as the assistant editor
of the similar publication at
Washington University.
"Of course I'm not satisfied with
our work. The 2 previous editors
have given us a tough model to live
up to. I would just like to continue
that tradition of excellence." During
the year it was under Armbruster's
editorship, the Johns Hopkins
Journal was adjudged 1 of the top 5
alumni newspapers in the country.
"What I like best about this place
is that with few exceptions people let
you alone to do what you do best."
That's probably true, though
Armbruster, who shoots in the mid80's, also enjoys being coach of the
golf team. "I love it." His pay is
several dozen golf balls.

Basics of Governance
By J. WOODFORD HOWARD
and STEWART HULSE
The governance committee was charged
to "design a more effective system of
governance" for the Division of Arts and
Sciences. To further understanding of the
report in the light of the reactions we have
heard since the report appeared, we desire
to underscore certain major principles
underlying the proposals as we comprehend
them.
The basic assumption of the majority
report is that the central purpose of the
Division is acquisition and expansion of
knowledge -- not campus politics. Consequently, the majority rejected various
proposals for government by town-meeting
or representative parliament and adopted
the principle of accountable administration,
as suggested by President Kingman
Brewster of Yale.
According to Brewster, there are two
reasons why a parliamentary body is
inappropriate to university governance.
First, decision-making by Democratic
representatives of all elements in a
diverse university is apt to be too
slow and ineffective to meet the
demands for prompt and flexible
leadership rising from many quarters.
Second, decision-making by a representative parliament would inevitably subordinate learning to campus politics for large
numbers -- and, we would add, create in
practice a new class of transient oligarchs no
less difficult to control than a few visible
administrators. Experiments on other
campuses confirm these difficulties. Thus
we concluded that what Hopkins needs is
neither cooption of administrative authority
by faculty and students nor an unwieldy
legislature. What Hopkins needs are
mechanisms to make administrative
authority more responsive, responsible, and
therefore supportable.
Hight to Participate
Though the concept of accountability may
sound fancy, the idea is simple. If consistently with their educational goals faculty

and students- cannot directly govern the
university, they can and should have the
right to participate in the selection of major
administrative officials, the right to be informed and consulted about policies affecting their vital interests, the right to
explanation of decisions reached, and the
right to periodic review of performance in
order to register or withhold their confidence. Otherwise, responsible administrators cannot reasonably expect their
cooperation and sustained support.
Our proposals seek to implement the
principle of accountable administration in
three ways:
(1) creation of more representative advisory bodies, (e.g., the ASRC, the judicial
institutions, etc.);
(2) clarification and realignment of functions, (e.g., the transfer of all nonacademic
matters from the Academic Council to the
ASRC); and
(3) recognition of administrative and
departmental guidelines as customary
standards of participation and conduct to
insure more effective communication,
consultation, and cooperation. It should be
stressed that these guidelines, which range
from fixed terms of service to guaranteed
fiscal information to advisory bodies, are
integral to the proposed design. Different
structures might well have been recommended without them. Particular proposals
regarding structure and functions should
therefore be read with the guidelines in
mind.
Weighted Interests
Another principle underlying the report is
organization according to weighted interests. Each major element of the Division - faculty, students, professional research

exclusive jurisdiction, dominant jurisdiction, and overlapping jurisdiction. For
example, the faculty have primary
responsibility for academic programs, while
students dominate extra-curricular activities. The faculty have exclusive advisory

Basics of Governance
By J. WOODFORD HOWARD
and STEWART HULSE
The governance committee was charged
to "design a more effective system of
governance" for the Division of Arts and
Sciences. To further understanding of the
report in the light of the reactions we have
heard since the report appeared, we desire
to underscore certain major principles
underlying the proposals as we comprehend
them.
The basic assumption of the majority
report is that the central purpose of the
Division is acquisition and expansion of
knowledge -- not campus politics. Consequently, the majority rejected various
proposals for government by town-meeting
or representative parliament and adopted
the principle of accountable administration,
as suggested by President Kingman
Brewster of Yale.
According to Brewster, there are two
reasons why a parliamentary body is
inappropriate to university governance.
First, decision-making by Democratic
representatives of all elements in a
diverse university is apt to be too
slow and ineffective to meet the
demands for prompt and flexible
leadership rising from many quarters.
Second, decision-making by a representative parliament would inevitably subordinate learning to campus politics for large
numbers -- and, we would add, create in
practice a new class of transient oligarchs no
less difficult to control than a few visible
administrators. Experiments on other
campuses confirm these difficulties. Thus
we concluded that what Hopkins needs is
neither cooption of administrative authority
by faculty and students nor an unwieldy
legislature. What Hopkins needs are
mechanisms to make administrative
authority more responsive, responsible, and
therefore supportable.
Hight to Participate
Though the concept of accountability may
sound fancy, the idea is simple. If consistently with their educational goals faculty

and students- cannot directly govern the
university, they can and should have the
right to participate in the selection of major
administrative officials, the right to be informed and consulted about policies affecting their vital interests, the right to
explanation of decisions reached, and the
right to periodic review of performance in
order to register or withhold their confidence. Otherwise, responsible administrators cannot reasonably expect their
cooperation and sustained support.
Our proposals seek to implement the
principle of accountable administration in
three ways:
(1) creation of more representative advisory bodies, (e.g., the ASRC, the judicial
institutions, etc.);
(2) clarification and realignment of functions, (e.g., the transfer of all nonacademic
matters from the Academic Council to the
ASRC); and
(3) recognition of administrative and
departmental guidelines as customary
standards of participation and conduct to
insure more effective communication,
consultation, and cooperation. It should be
stressed that these guidelines, which range
from fixed terms of service to guaranteed
fiscal information to advisory bodies, are
integral to the proposed design. Different
structures might well have been recommended without them. Particular proposals
regarding structure and functions should
therefore be read with the guidelines in
mind.
Weighted Interests
Another principle underlying the report is
organization according to weighted interests. Each major element of the Division - faculty, students, professional research

exclusive jurisdiction, dominant jurisdiction, and overlapping jurisdiction. For

responsibility for academic programs, while
students dominate extra-curricular activities. The faculty have exclusive advisory
